text.p: Following are the main stories in Slovenia's Friday morning newspapers.
- A European Commission source said Slovenia would be among six countries to be invited to start negotiations on full membership of the European Union next year.
- Due to higher taxes petrol prices in Slovenia will be raised by six percent from Saturday.
- Parliament on Thursday started debating laws that would protect national interests once Slovenia becomes an associate member of the EU.

- The parliamentary board for constitutional changes detailed the change to the 68th article of the constitution which would enable foreigners to buy land. The parliament is expected to take a vote on whether to adopt the change on Monday.
- Credit agency Dun & Bradstreet said the decision of president Milan Kucan to stand for re-election this year improved Slovenia's political risk.

- Inofficial sources claim parliamentary president Janez Podobnik, a member of the conservative People's Party, could run for President in elections later this year although the party has so far denied such a possibility.
- Eleven members of parliament pushed for a July parliamentary debate on laws that would help less developed regions in Slovenia.
- The oppositional centre-right Social Democratic Party said it would demand an extra parliamentary session regarding Slovenia's failure to be included in the first round of NATO expansion.
